**Online Literary Criticism For Everyone**
**Is do-it-yourself literary criticism just harmless fun?**
From the beginning, the idea of open access to the Internet was a key principle. In theory, anyone could publish their thoughts or start a music channel online. In practice, though, some technical skills were needed, especially in the early days. However, one area that was truly opened to everyone was literary criticism. By visiting Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could write a book review. Amazon's approach to book reviews was simple: anyone could say what they liked about a book and give it up to five stars. This seemed like a great idea. Each book had its own page on Amazon's site, and when a reader submitted a new review, it appeared automatically. This allowed Amazon to fill its pages with free reviews, and potential buyers could see what other readers thought of a book, rather than just reading the publisher's description or professional critics' opinions. Other online bookstores, which also had physical stores, offered similar features. But as the largest player, with over 80% of the online market, Amazon had the most customers and attracted the most reviews, which also led to some problems. 
This open system allowed for some mischief. Thousands of reviews were submitted each day, so it was impossible to check them all. Instead, a team of editors checked that reviews followed the company's guidelines. Reviews with just one word, personal attacks on the author, or those with bad language, spoilers, or references to other reviews were not allowed. However, reviewers were anonymous and reviews were only removed if Amazon's editors noticed them. This meant there was room for trouble. For example, writers could give their own books great reviews. One writer, Lev Grossman, was upset by the bad reviews his first novel received, so he wrote some positive ones himself. His trick worked until he wrote an article about it, and the fake reviews were removed. Authors could also comment on their books by clicking a link that said, "I am the Author, and I wish to comment on my book." Most authors used this to post friendly messages hoping people would buy and enjoy their book. Some even shared their email addresses to invite readers to contact them. However, Amazon did not check if these comments really came from the author, except for famous writers. A lesser-known writer once pretended to be John Updike and wrote a fake comment, which was removed.
The real drama came from readers, not writers. When James McElroy's book "We've Got Spirit," about a small-town cheerleading team, was published, it was well-received by the mainstream press. But many people mentioned in the book felt betrayed and used Amazon's page to express their anger. Dozens of critical reviews were submitted but disappeared a few days later. Despite this, Amazon saw the large number of people reading and writing reviews as good for business. Since readers' reviews were meant to be a "forum to talk about a book" rather than a chat room, Amazon closely monitored bestselling books to ensure reviews followed the rules. This meant that the best place to post a silly review was on a page for a less popular book. "The Story about Ping," a classic children's book about a duck named Ping, inspired much humor because "ping" is also a term used in Internet technology. One long review compared the book's plot to Internet architecture and concluded it provided a "good high-level overview" of basic networking concepts. However, such silliness was rare. Most reader reviews on Amazon.com were taken seriously by their writers and provided a surprisingly accurate idea of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once complained that reviewing too many books meant inventing reactions to books he had no real feelings about. This is why the democratization of the review process can be seen as a positive development.

**Art in Modern Times**
In the last two hundred years, people have started to think that every artist must be different from others. We often praise art for being unique, revolutionary, or even shocking. We admire artists whose work was not appreciated a hundred years ago. But when it comes to modern art, we sometimes hesitate and say an artist has gone too far, or that their work is not art anymore. The media often say this for us, and we agree because we expect art to be confusing and new. We don't always see the old themes and methods in today's art. We think artists should be different from everyone else, with special talents that break the rules. In the past, people asked artists to create art for specific reasons, and it was part of everyday life. Today, we let artists do what they want and get upset if they try to be more like us.
**Picture This**
Let me describe a situation and ask an important question. An artist picks a piece of text from an art book. The text talks about the many different kinds of pictures. The artist then asks someone to make a canvas and take it to a sign painter. The sign painter writes the text on the canvas in simple black letters, without any fancy style. My question is: Is this finished product a painting?
**Underground Encounters**
At the Mercury Gallery in London until June 26th
Usually, when a painter finds success in one style, they stick to it. Collectors expect artists to keep doing the same thing, and trying something new can upset people. Gallery owners like safe choices, and art buyers often want the comfort of familiarity. Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, successfully try new things. Eric Rimmington is another artist trying something different. He is known for his still life paintings but is now painting scenes from the London Underground. Rimmington has always been interested in railways. In the 1980s, he drew pictures of the railway land at King's Cross Station. Now, he has moved underground to explore what happens there. His new show, "Underground Encounters," includes 40 paintings and drawings that capture the unique world of the London Underground.
**Extract from a Novel**
I have come to this island with a few books. I don't know why I say "escape." The villagers joke that only a sick person would come to such a remote place to rebuild. So, I am here to heal myself, if you want to say it that way. Except for an old woman who comes from the village each day to clean, I am alone. I am neither happy nor unhappy; I feel like I am floating in memories. I talked about how art seems useless but didn't mention its comforts. The comfort of creating art is that it allows us to change reality and show its true meaning. Our everyday actions are like a rough cloth hiding the beautiful pattern underneath. For artists, art is a way to deal with the things that hurt or defeated us in life. It helps us fulfill our true potential through imagination. Otherwise, why would we hurt each other?

Title: Family Business
"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were driving back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from the fancy girls' school I attended. He had also just been to Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the prize for doing best in my final exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were heading home for the holidays. 
"What isn't?" I asked, though I had a feeling I knew what he was thinking because he was unusually quiet. Normally, he talked a lot. 
"You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you might get a scholarship to Oxford."
"So?" I said, trying to act confident. "Couldn't that be useful?"
"I also heard," he continued, and I knew a serious talk was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.
"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"
"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can understand a lot of information quickly, you can talk well, and you like performing."
"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see in TV dramas."
"Anyway," he said, pulling himself together, "I feel your heart's not going to be in the family business now. You'll go to Oxford, and after that, I can't see you wanting to join us."
Like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by family expectations. I saw other career options and wanted to explore them. At the same time, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him intimidating.
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.
"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," my father said, and he was usually right about these things, "and it's a pity because you have the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."
"There's still Maurice," I said, sulking. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.
"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a sort of consultant."
My mother wasn't around to help - she died when I was young, and my father raised Maurice and me. Maurice was two years younger, and because he was motherless, I got used to taking care of him. It wasn't hard. I loved Maurice. Because the business was successful, we lived in luxury - a big house in London, fancy schools, nice clothes, parties, theaters, operas. My father knew many people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was full of interesting conversations.
"I tell you what," my father continued. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave us, you can. It will give you some pocket money and be a real help to me."
"OK," I said, relieved to avoid making immediate decisions and especially to avoid my father's sulks if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.
So it happened. In my last term at school, and then during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on the safer tasks. I became one of the smarter students, with a little house of my own, a small but powerful white car, designer clothes, and a black dress with a Paris label that I planned to wear for my final exams.
In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew that if I stayed focused and used these last days wisely, he might be right. I felt ready, confident, and focused.
But that was not to be. My father told me that in about a week, he needed me to do one last job for him. It was the most important work the family business had ever done, and he promised it would be worth my while.
"But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It's really important that I do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now."
I could tell that my father couldn't understand this pressure (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him?) and that he would see a refusal as a betrayal in his time of need. That wasn't all. As he explained the job, I saw more clearly than ever his determination - the clarity and skill with which he approached his work, his energy, and his self-control. In his way, he was a genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans seem less important.
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being very careful with their money, which wasn't ideal. At first, it seemed like a good decision because Simon had many successful cases, and Lois had returned to her job at an advertising agency after having twins. She even got a raise, making her salary thirty-five thousand. Lois was the one who really wanted to move, and Simon didn't argue much. She felt their flat wasn't suitable for a family, and they needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. They could have found these things in a less expensive area, but Lois wanted more than just space. She wanted a prestigious address for their careers. Mornington Mansions didn't fit the image of a successful barrister and businesswoman. Lois decided they needed to save money, so one of them had to use public transport. Since her job was far away, Simon had to take the crowded tube, which made him unhappy. He often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he stayed as a boy. His grandmother always made sure his grandfather, a lawyer, was comfortable after work. But times had changed. Lois made it clear before they married that her career was as important as his. They needed both salaries to maintain their lifestyle. Now, their situation was threatened by Venetia, who was very upset. She accused Simon of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, had bribed jurors in a case four years ago and that Cartwright had given shares to Simon's fiancée before the trial. Simon denied it, but his denial sounded weak even to himself. He felt guilty and remembered being punished as a child. He wished he had been prepared and said something different. Venetia's anger and disgust confused him. He wondered why she was so upset and if she had the right to ruin his career. If the rumor spread, he knew his career would be over.

I chose to live here because I thought I could be anonymous among people who didn't care if the rented houses were falling apart or if the gardens were overgrown. But I was wrong. People in the shops start to recognize you, even if you don't feel like you're living a real life. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside to forget about summer, but tonight I'm watching the birds fly between the trees and roofs. I cleared some space in the garden for a chair, and my arms are scratched from cutting back plants. It's a small London garden where plants have to grow tall to survive. 
My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She's written several unpublished books, and as an English teacher, I sometimes have to pretend to be interested. I have her latest book now. 'How's the writing going, Jaz?' I ask. 'In no other job do people ask you about your work so much,' she replies. Then she offers to bring a drink down. I don't really want her in the garden, which now looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. 'You're on holiday now,' she says, sitting in the chair. 'I should've been a teacher. Writers don't get holidays. They say those who can, do, and those who can't, teach.' And some can't do either. 'What are your plans for the holidays?' she asks. 
I feel anxious about the school year ending. Empty days, hot streets, and loneliness in the park. 'I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?' I ask, my heart racing. 'Of course,' Jaz says, knowing she will be around. 'Where will you stay?' she asks. 'With my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun,' I lie. I often deal with fiction. 'Going back to your roots. What do you think of my book?' Jaz asks about her manuscript, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I haven't finished reading. I like the title and tell her so. I decide to be honest. 'Try writing about nice people for a change,' I suggest. 'Teachers!' Jaz responds like a rebellious student. 'I keep a journal where I write something good about each day,' I say, sounding old-fashioned. 'Get a life, Ann,' Jaz replies. 
I do have a life. I work, go out, and read on the tube. When we go inside, my kitchen feels calming. Then I suddenly remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now, winking at us and saying, 'I've had my moments.' We almost died laughing.

**Heritage**
Heritage is important because it helps people and communities feel connected to the past. We often feel linked to our personal heritage, like knowing about our grandparents and their stories. But there is also a need to learn about our broader past to understand our future, both individually and as a nation. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity, helping us feel secure about the future by understanding the past. Just like we inherit our genes, we also inherit a culture passed down through generations. There might be parts of our national heritage we don't like, but it is still part of us, and it feels good to belong to something. Heritage teaches us a lot and is essential for our well-being. It influences everything from customs to material culture. In the past, we connected with our history through stories and legends from our ancestors. However, Western industrial society broke up communities, and much of this oral tradition has been lost. Now, places and buildings help us learn about our past. It is crucial to preserve these links to honor our ancestors' identity.
**The Fens**
I started writing a novel called "Waterland," where the landscape of the Fens in England became very important. People often ask why I, a Londoner with no personal connection to the Fens, chose to write about it. The simple answer is that I picked the Fens because they seemed plain and empty, a perfect setting for my story. But I learned that the Fens are not flat or empty. They are as English as any other part of England but also strangely unique. It's surprising that in the middle of England, there is a place that feels foreign to many English people, even though other unique areas of Britain have become part of the nation's cultural heritage. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated and wild, open yet mysterious. While writing my novel, I didn't explore the Fens extensively. I haven't been to places like Wisbech or Prickwillow. As a fiction writer, I prefer to imagine worlds rather than rely on facts. Imagining the Fens has its own logic because, as Edward Storey's book shows, the Fens are not just a landscape but also a state of mind.
**Museums**
Museums need to make their collections easy to access. In the past, this meant putting items in display cases with long labels that were hard to understand. Today, accessibility means more than that. Displays should be lively and interesting, using techniques to capture visitors' attention and emotions. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can provide loan boxes of objects for teachers or use similar materials to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real artifacts and specimens, not replicas. They offer a chance to see and learn from items that existed and had meaning in history. This is what makes them different from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and CDs. Museums that create exciting and accessible displays and programs will find that virtual history can actually help them by increasing interest in the real things that only museums can offer.
**Architecture and Environment**
The desire to preserve things is not new, but changes in our towns happen so quickly now that they affect most of us. This makes some people want to preserve everything, while others think more about the nature and future of towns. It can be argued that people who have lived through events like world wars are more interested in preservation because stability becomes important. If there is a need for preservation, planners should consider it. Change is not bad if we learn how to manage it. Physical changes in our towns reflect social changes, like changes in population, welfare, and demands.

**Einstein**
If you ask someone on the street to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is often used to sell smart products like computers and encyclopedias. Most people don't know much about what Einstein did, except that he created theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that seem different from everyday life. Einstein was part of a big change in scientific thinking, which started modern science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to describe the universe better by studying how matter and natural forces interact. Einstein made important contributions by rethinking basic ideas like time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, people followed Isaac Newton's idea that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this by saying that time and space are not fixed but relative.
**Young Readers**
When we were children, Lydia and I didn't trust books that won prizes because we thought they would be 'worthy', which to us meant 'boring'. Our mother didn't like our attitude and would hint at her disapproval, but our father would happily give us small amounts of money to encourage us to read these books. He would also sneak in a few good books among our Christmas and birthday gifts, marking them with 'This Book is NOT Literature'. Although we ignored most of these books as 'boys' books', he did manage to get us to read some good short stories and, once, a famous collection of poems.
**Language**
In 1851, Jacob Grimm wrote that 'The origin of human language is truly secret and marvellous'. This mystery has led to many strange ideas. In 1928, Charles Caller said that early humans might have made sounds like "meuh" when they felt danger. "Meuh" sounds sad. People who lived in dangerous places with scary animals made desperate sounds, and some languages still have words that echo this, like 'malaria' meaning "fever" or the Latin 'mors' meaning "death". Because of these odd ideas, many people avoided the topic, thinking it was for eccentric thinkers. But recently, the origin and evolution of language have become important research areas. Language probably started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly communication and was important in power struggles. Sharing information was probably not its original purpose, even though philosopher John Locke thought of language as a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode looks at the skill of writing reviews from the perspective of someone who does it. Most reviews are written and shared in ways that make them last only a short time. There are deadlines and strict limits on how long they can be. Once published, they are only relevant for as long as the newspaper or magazine they appear in, which could be a day, a week, or at most a month. The short life of reviews often affects how people see their importance. Many people, including the writers, think that reviewing is a job done for reasons like needing money or because they can't spend all day working on a novel or a serious book. However, reviewing is a skilled and complex job. It's one thing to be quick and fair in a short newspaper review of six to eight hundred words, and another to write a detailed piece of six to eight thousand words for international journals. Writing a fifteen hundred-word article for weekly magazines combines challenges of both short and long reviews. Length isn't the only thing to consider. Reviewers must think about their audience, from casual readers to those deeply interested in the subject. A reviewer also needs to know a lot about many topics and write in a way that intelligent people can understand and enjoy. This means reviewers often write other things besides reviews. The American novelist John Updike, who doesn't think highly of criticism, still enjoys writing reviews between his novels. He collects all his reviews, even short ones, into books with modest titles. Some might think less famous writers should accept that their reviews are temporary, but if they can, they should be allowed to keep a record of their work, especially if they believe some of their best writing is in reviews. I feel this way about my own work. My main job has been academic, and most of my serious books are academic, the kind professors are expected to write. In the English-speaking world, unlike other cultures, it's common for the same people to do both reviewing and literary study. In the past, other academics criticized professors who reviewed for showing off or wasting time, but now it's more accepted. Complaints from non-professors that professors are taking their jobs are also less common, partly because there is more reviewing work available and partly because the pay is often low. I believe these arrangements are good for readers, who can trust the reviewer knows what they're talking about, and for professors, as it helps them stay connected to a wider audience. It reminds them to communicate clearly with non-professors. Finally, reviewing should be a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and felt a brief moment of doubt about owning it, even after three years. When he first bought the flat, he would come home excitedly, wondering what had happened while he was away. The flat felt like a welcoming place where he was in control. He thought he should worry about things like intruders or leaks, but the flat always seemed to be waiting for him, either tidy or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as just another part of himself, filled with his thoughts and feelings. He became frustrated that it couldn't change. Sometimes, there would be a small pile of letters by the door or a blinking light on the answering machine when he got home. He was glad the windows weren't broken and nothing was stolen, but he wondered what it would look like if it had been. 
From his dull office on Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to spending three or four evenings alone at home each week. Once he left the office and started to feel like himself again on the bus ride home, he realized he didn't need to be alone. At his desk, he longed for time alone with his things, but once he got home, he felt empty and waited for a sense of self to return. Instead, he felt a deep emptiness, making him think that doing work he didn't like had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was. He would read or listen to music at night, but he started to question why he did these things. His thoughts and feelings seemed unclear and disconnected. 
There was a time, he thought, when he didn't feel so powerless. If he had realized his own value, he might have escaped his situation. But he was eager to settle down and followed the first opportunity that came along. After university, he tried to make a plan for his future, but he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs his friends talked about and followed their paths, not imagining he could find a job that would make him happy. He went to one job interview and didn't think much about whether the job was right for him. It was an editorial role at a free local newspaper. He was relieved to have a pleasant conversation with Neil, his boss, and didn't think about the long meetings he would have to attend. Neil offered him the job right away, saying Ralph was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**
I was about to see goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I pushed through ice-cream vans, lots of people, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was moving towards the racecourse, but I tried hard to find a good spot. A part of the area was marked off for the race. It wasn't like big racecourses, but people stood on both sides of the track where the goats would run. It was hard to keep the goats in order because they are known to eat almost anything.
**Canoe Trip**
As the day ended, I started to worry about the night. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and we hadn't seen any villages or huts since the morning. In the dim moonlight, we used our torch to see the cliffs, but the torch batteries were dying. We put in new ones, but they didn't work. We couldn't find a place to camp. A few miles later, Lesley thought she saw a light, and we got hopeful. But it was just moonlight on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud noise of fast water, but we couldn't see what was happening. Time seemed to stop as we moved on.
**How to be Presentation Perfect - we answer your questions**
I am not good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and major shareholders. How can I improve my presentation skills and confidence? 
You are not alone. Presenting is a different skill from running a company, but many senior executives need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you are saying. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas before the presentation. Ask colleagues to think of difficult questions the audience might ask. Also, create a positive atmosphere from the start. Begin with something everyone agrees on and slowly build to your main point.

Some activities cannot be rushed; they take the time they need. If you're late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you add oil too quickly when making mayonnaise, it will curdle. If you pull too hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things it does very quickly, while others take longer. We can get faster at solving puzzles or doing math in our heads, but some mental tasks cannot be rushed. If we try to hurry them, they might fail, like the mayonnaise, or get more complicated, like the fishing line. 
The mind has different speeds for different tasks. Sometimes, we need to react instantly without thinking. For example, when my motorbike skidded on a wet road, my body reacted quickly to keep me safe before I even realized what was happening. This fast reaction is a type of intelligence called 'wits'. 
Then there is thinking, which involves figuring things out, weighing options, and solving problems. A mechanic fixing an engine or a student working on an assignment uses this kind of intelligence, which we call 'intellect'. People who are good at this are often called 'bright' or 'clever'.
There is also a slower way of thinking that is more relaxed and dreamy. This happens when we are lost in thought, like sitting by the sea or just before falling asleep. This slow thinking is just as important as fast thinking. It helps us understand complex or unclear situations. 
Recent studies show that this patient, less deliberate way of thinking is good for dealing with complicated problems. When we don't know what questions to ask or when the issue is too subtle, we need this slow thinking. For example, deciding how to manage a difficult group at work or whether to change careers might be better solved by pondering rather than rushing for answers. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and wisdom.
Poets and philosophers have long understood the limits of fast, deliberate thinking and have valued these slower ways of knowing. Scientists are now exploring these slower, less deliberate ways of thinking. They find that the unconscious mind can learn complex patterns, understand complicated situations, and solve difficult problems if given time.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**
I have been welcomed warmly. It's a friendly and well-supplied base camp in a very isolated place. At any time, there are about forty people - scientists, students, weather experts, and satellite trackers - in a close community where everyone helps each other. My basic French is just enough to communicate, but not to have casual conversations. I miss the small details, and my phrasebook is useless at breakfast. This isn't a practical problem for me, but at first, it affected my self-confidence. I was a bit nervous about mealtimes. I would hesitate, unsure about which table to choose, worried about the silence when I spoke, and anxious like I was in my first weeks of school. I still smile awkwardly or panic when people talk to me. I think the reason for my occasional sadness is not about losing company or communication, but because I've lost the social advantage that my ability to talk has always given me.
**Elliot**
When I first met Elliot, I was just a young author like any other, and he didn't pay much attention to me. He never forgot a face though, and when I saw him here or there, he shook hands with me politely but didn't try to get to know me better. If I saw him at the opera with someone important, he often pretended not to see me. But then I had a big success as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot started to like me more. One day, he sent me a note inviting me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me. After that, because my success brought me many new friends, I began to see him more often.
**Alfred Hitchcock**
The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said he didn't care about the story of his films or the acting, but he did care about the photography, the soundtrack, and all the technical parts. For Hitchcock, it wasn't a message or a great performance that moved the audience. He believed that people are excited by pure film, no matter their cultural background. So, if a film is made correctly, in terms of its emotional impact, the Japanese audience should scream at the same moment as the Indian audience. Hitchcock's view of himself was always clear and logical. He was a man of reason and a talented craftsman who liked to hear an audience scream. He didn't deal with guesses, abstract ideas, or intellectual hints, and he didn't explore his own screen characters deeply. He focused on film, pure film, and the precise, calculated beauty of what a strip of film can do to an audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**
Astronomy has changed a lot in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts or catalogues. Telescopes were basic, and there were few books on how to do astronomy. Today, you can buy many different telescopes and equipment. Electronic calculators and computers have made it easier to create charts and analyze observations. This might be the best time for amateur astronomy. However, some things have been lost. Now, you might need to travel 80 km to find a sky as clear as it was in cities 50 years ago. During the day, airplane trails can turn into clouds, making it hard to observe the sun and stars.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, there are too many choices. There are too many things to do and too many options. People always want the newest product or service, and technology makes changes happen faster. New products come out quickly, and it can be overwhelming. More choices can mean more stress, less time, and more complexity. Because of this, people are looking for 'simplexity'—simple things that bring meaning in a complex world. But simplifying life is hard when there are so many products and services. There are more types of detergent and breakfast cereals than we need, and more software updates and phone plans than we can follow.
**McAndrews Hotel**
Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition started by my grandmother, and it is very important to us. We do not let anything disturb this tradition. The people who stay at McAndrews are similar: old-fashioned and maybe a bit snobbish. I do not like the rude behavior of shop assistants today, which is seen as being equal. I also do not like waiters being too friendly. I know most of the guests' names because they have been coming here since they were children, like me. But I can be sure that when I see them in the hotel, we will only exchange polite greetings. Respect for privacy is rare in hotels these days.

**Othello**
A special production of Shakespeare's play "Othello" has moved from Stratford to London. This gives me a chance to correct a negative review I wrote when the show first opened last spring. At that time, I said Ray Fearon was too young for the main role and criticized his acting. I still believe that changing the age difference between Othello and Desdemona affects the story, but I take back my criticism of Mr. Fearon's amazing performance. In fact, the entire cast is excellent. Some unforgettable scenes include Cassio's dangerous games with other young officers and the moment when Iago starts to lose control and struggles to regain it. I dare anyone not to cry during the scene where Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed. The pace and tension are fantastic throughout. Don't miss this production.
**Lake Vostok**
In the middle of Antarctica, nothing moves. On the edges of the continent, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. But on the large white plateau inside, there is no life. Except for a huge hidden freshwater lake called Lake Vostok, which is under almost 4 kilometers of ice, right below the coldest place on earth. The water has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are eager to explore its mysterious depths and find out what strange creatures live there. Geologists and glaciologists are also very interested. For two years, researchers from around the world have been planning how to uncover the lake's secrets. If they succeed, the next few years will be known as the decade of Lake Vostok.
**Scientists**
There was an interesting discussion on the radio last week. It seems that some scientists are getting very excited about what motivates them to be scientists. The phrase "because it's there" comes to mind. We all know it's the age-old search for knowledge, the desire to understand everything from atoms to black holes. But these scientists want to know why we want to know all of this in the first place and why science can't explain our curiosity. Surely, it's more important to know if what scientists are doing is right, rather than getting stuck in debates about the purpose of it all. Words typed quickly lack the care and personality of handwriting.

Birds have always been important in human culture. But what does this say about us? Paul Evans explores this idea. In a greenhouse, a small brown bird, a wren, is hitting the glass. Wrens are seen as mysterious birds, sometimes thought to bring messages or signs. Is this wren trying to tell me something, or is it just trapped? Both ideas could be true, depending on how you see it. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed the direction a wren flew could predict their luck. Today, wrens are still popular in British art and homes. Even if old beliefs are forgotten, wrens still hold a special place in our hearts. A forest without wrens feels empty. This is because many birds are part of our folklore, which goes back to when people relied more on nature for survival. People developed a way of understanding the world through the behavior of animals. This understanding can change over time. For example, the red kite was once a common bird in London, seen as helpful because it cleaned the streets. But later, it was seen as a pest and almost disappeared, except in Wales. Now, red kites are protected and have become symbols of conservation in Britain. Our connection with birds is not just cultural; it is part of our nature. Early humans watched birds closely because they could warn of danger, bad weather, or food. Birds also connected people to their dreams. When we think about why birds matter to us, we also think about what it means to be human. Birds represent flight, song, and freedom, which we admire and wish to have. Some people might say these feelings are old and not needed now, but they are still part of us. Birds are now seen as indicators of environmental health. In Britain, 30 bird species are endangered, which is sad not only because we lose these birds but also because we lose part of our culture. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing have deep cultural meanings, representing love and magic. Losing them is like losing a part of our history. However, birds not mentioned in stories or folklore are often ignored when they disappear. Folklore is important because it keeps stories and feelings about birds alive, more than scientific terms can. These stories help us connect with birds in a way that science cannot explain. Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel is hard to describe with science. Birds engage us in ways we don't fully understand, and the stories we tell about them help us interpret their messages. The wren in the greenhouse creates a link between the present and the past, holding a mystery that keeps us curious.

**Maps**
A map is a tool that shows how different places and features on Earth relate to each other. This is done by showing distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance by time, like saying "a few hours' walk" or "a day's journey by river." This told more about how easy it was to travel through the area than the actual distance. 
Direction is another important part of maps, but for most travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far is it?" So, exact direction wasn't always the most important thing. Because of this, written travel guides were often used instead of maps. Even today, some maps, like those for train systems, might not show true directions. Early maps also used signs to show important landmarks, and these signs could be different sizes to show how important they were. The style of these signs changed depending on the map's purpose and where it was made. So, when looking at old maps, it's important to understand the style used.
The history of map-making, or cartography, is about making maps more accurate in showing distance and direction and adding more details. To do this, cartographers used other sciences. For example, instead of using the sun or stars to find direction, they used the magnetic compass. They also developed tools to measure angles accurately. As people explored more of the world, they tried to map it. Astronomers found out that Earth is not a perfect sphere but is slightly flat at the poles, which made mapping large areas more precise.
Over time, different people needed maps for different reasons. Travelers and merchants were not the only ones using maps. Soldiers needed accurate maps, especially with the use of artillery, to understand the land better. This led to the invention of contour lines to show elevation. Archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also needed maps for their work. Today's map makers, or cartographers, create maps showing many things, like geological layers, climate, and land use. The value of maps in many sciences has led to a modern revival of map-making.
The development of maps has not always been smooth. There have been times of slow progress and times of rapid change. Sometimes old ideas stayed around even when new ones were available. Cartographers often knew how to improve maps but had to wait for better tools. Since it was easy to copy old maps, and because of the cost of printing, map publishers were sometimes slow to accept new ideas. Therefore, maps should not always be seen as perfect evidence of what people knew at the time.
The many maps we have today are the result of much work and thought. They are a valuable record of human history and make the study of historical maps both interesting and educational.

I was invited into a young man's living room, which felt like a calm and cultured place compared to the messy rooms around it where his less ambitious family members stayed. Moving from the kitchen to his living room felt like going from economy to business class on a plane. In his room, I saw the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had come across, and surprisingly, a teenager who had spent money on Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months free before starting. During this time, he wanted to become England's version of the composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as crazy; I wanted to be a pop star for reasons like women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams were not as serious to me, although I might have felt differently if I had failed. So, when Andrew suggested a new crazy goal for me—to become as famous a lyricist as Oscar Hammerstein—I was willing to try. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting, he played me three tunes he had composed, and I could tell he was very talented. As he confidently played selections from the many shows he had written and produced at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' record collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I didn't have much to impress him with, except for praising his music and showing him a seven-inch single of a song I had written, which an unknown pop group had recorded three months earlier. We agreed to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in West End theatre, but on the bus back to my flat, I told myself I had just met someone with rare talent and determination, and I would be foolish to miss the chance to work with him. Even if we didn't succeed in musical theatre, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and might need new songs. The next day, back at my desk in the office where I was training to become a lawyer, my brief certainty of a life in show business with Andrew Lloyd Webber faded a bit. I would keep looking at ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a singer and write more simple songs that didn't show my voice's limitations, but it seemed likely I would eventually pass my exams and become a respectable lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. By then, I would probably have outgrown pop music, as my father predicted I would by the time I was twenty-one. This worried me—if he was right, I only had a few more months to enjoy it. But in the meantime, I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to see a musical with him and write lyrics like musical lyricists instead of pop stars. Andrew was an interesting person who talked about Good Food Guides and Victorian architecture and supported the Leyton Orient football team. I wasn't convinced by the idea for a musical he had been working on for the past year, but in 1965, I was rarely convinced about anything. His talent was undeniable, and he claimed to have all the contacts. I soon returned to his living room. The idea was about the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo, the nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded the orphanages named after him. His story was indeed worthy, but it didn't really excite me. The hero was too perfect, at least in Andrew's version, and the project was unoriginal, similar to Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. On the other hand, Andrew's belief in his music's brilliance was contagious and not entirely wrong. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who later became my agent for over twenty-five years, often said, if there's a demand for one hamburger bar on the block, there's room for two. We could be the second hamburger joint. I started working with great enthusiasm, especially on the songs meant to be funny. Andrew explained the plot, played me the tunes, and often gave me the titles, most of which were probably thought up by his previous lyricist friend. I skipped a day at the solicitor's office, pretending to be sick, to write my first set of theatrical lyrics. I didn't know it then, but I had changed careers.
