If you're not fasting or on a light diet, you eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty and nicely presented, so you don't suffer too much! You get a massage or water therapy every other day. All extra treatments are reasonably priced. - Liz Gregory
**C. CAREYS MANOR**
Careys is not a health farm and doesn't claim to be. It's a lovely old manor farm with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge. If you're watching your calories, you'll have to skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and delightful creamy desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a fully-equipped gym and a soft-water pool, so I could work off some of the tempting treats. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you really want to lose weight.) There is a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got expert advice on an old, sometimes painful, shoulder injury. The physiotherapist recommended good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around. - Beverly D'Silva
**D. CLIVEDEN**
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful woodland walks and gardens on the 376-acre National Trust estate. Waldo's, a highly-rated restaurant, has dishes that are hard to resist. It took me half an hour to read the dinner menu; the choices were amazing. The meal was wonderful, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed a happy woman! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. I thought about the other reports my fellow journalists would write, about fitness assessments, workouts, and beauty treatments to tone and firm the body. Cliveden has all these if you want to use them—before enjoying yourself at Waldo's. - Kay Letch
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It's the best because it's the most delicious I've ever tasted. It's the worst because it's a large piece with 360 calories, which isn't good if you want to lose weight. You've been warned! The second best thing is the amazing aromatherapy massage. I chose the relaxing oils blend, fell asleep twice during the massage, floated back to my room, and had my most refreshing night's sleep in years. The place is modern and purpose-built, efficiently run, with up-to-date facilities and luxurious bedrooms. There are plenty of therapists and beauty rooms, so it's easy to schedule appointments. They offer a variety of treatments, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a mix of people—from entire football teams to mothers and daughters, best friends, and singles. Ideally, I would take a break here about once a month. - Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the seven million years since humans split from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much genetically. We are still more than 98% the same as chimps. On a big evolutionary scale, what makes humans different from animals is a recent change. Our ability to make art and do other things we think are uniquely human must come from a small part of our genes. This is a lot to expect from just a few genes. It's not surprising that studies of animal behavior show that many things we thought were only human are actually shared with animals, just in different degrees. For example, both humans and animals like chimpanzees and sea otters use tools. Chimps use sticks to eat and as weapons, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings show that there are few absolute differences between us and animals, except for art.
If human art comes from a unique genetic gift, it's strange that our ancestors didn't make art for most of the 7 million years since they split from chimps. The earliest art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we can't know for sure because those materials don't last. Clear evidence of human art, like cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments, only appears with the Cro-Magnons around 35,000 years ago.
If we say our recent creativity sets us apart, how is our art different from similar animal works? Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it's made for beauty, and it's learned, not instinctive. Let's look at these claims.
First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means human art doesn't help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike most animal behaviors. While human art can communicate thoughts or feelings, it's not the same as passing on genes. Birdsong, for example, helps defend territory or attract a mate, which helps pass on genes. By this measure, human art seems different.
The second claim is that only human art is made for aesthetic pleasure. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during breeding season, so they probably don't sing just for pleasure. Again, human art seems unique here.
The third difference is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing their species' song. A French baby raised in Japan wouldn't spontaneously sing the French national anthem. Human art changes quickly, unlike animal behaviors. For example, geese honked 2,000 years ago just like they do today, but human art styles change fast. Even a casual museum visitor can tell a 20th-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often identify when and who painted a work. However, they might mistake the works of two mid-20th-century artists, Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show in 1957 at London's Institute of Contemporary Art, and most of their paintings sold, which many human artists can't claim.
These paintings by chimps blur the lines between human art and animal activities. Like human art, the ape paintings weren't made for practical reasons but for the painter's satisfaction. You might say human art is different because it's meant to communicate, but even some famous human art was made for the artist's personal satisfaction.

Title: A Big Adventure
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on earth that people have not explored. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived to tell his story. Today, there are not many big adventures or heroes left. In the past, children's stories often featured brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes focused on the far horizon as they traveled into the unknown. Nowadays, such people are rare in both fiction and real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore led a team across the Taklamakan Desert, one of the last unexplored places on earth. Its name means 'once entered you never come out', and locals call it the Desert of Death. He shared the dangers and excitement of this incredible journey from the comfort of his home. His team included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. Surprisingly, the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were actually long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have been very dangerous and put the expedition at risk.
This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the world's toughest deserts. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At the time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to prove something to himself. 'I always thought I'd spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to find out who Charles Blackmore really was, outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took us 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us.'
Anyone reading about their crossing might wonder why he used the word 'kind'. The team faced many hardships: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst and dehydration, and losing part of their precious water supply. 'But', Blackmore explains, 'when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn't experience the Taklamakan's famous sandstorms. And we never faced the freezing desert cold that could have stopped us completely. That's not to say we didn't face challenges. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and the heavily loaded camels, which often fell over onto us.'
'What kept me going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn't allow for one. No aircraft flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very worried about my physical ability. I remember the first day -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We have to do it now!" At that moment, I was very scared.'
If it was like that at the beginning, how did they feel towards the end? 'When you've walked 1,000 kilometers, you're not going to give up. You've gone through so much; you've come so far. We were very thin but strong and muscular despite being exhausted. My body was in great shape, and my legs were like machines. I could walk over anything.'
In the middle of the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon, and thinking of his family. How aware was he of the difficulty it must have been for them? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace with himself. When I doubt myself now, I think back to the desert and remember that we managed to do that. As a personal achievement, I feel prouder of that expedition than anything else I've done. But in terms of a lifetime's achievement, I think of my family and the happiness we share -- compared to that, the desert doesn't measure up.'
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I long for the challenge -- for the open spaces -- the purpose of it all. We were lifted by the sense of purpose. I find it hard now to be part of the sameness of modern life.'

Life was becoming too hectic for Susan Harr, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand again. Everyone loves technology because it gives us amazing gadgets that make life easier and give us more free time. However, we've been subtly convinced that technology is essential, and that's okay. But is it really? Using our hands doesn't harm the environment, unlike machines. A recent problem with my word processor, which cost a lot to fix, made me think that gadgets might not be worth the trouble or expense. Are we as dependent on technology as we think? Gradually, I've been letting household gadgets go as they break down. This makes me question what "extra time" technology really gives us. Is it just more time to buy more gadgets? If so, the marketers have tricked us. When my machine started making strange noises, even when unplugged, I left it in the backyard. Now, I'm not stuck to a noisy machine, and I can take my time sewing by hand. I was always a bit scared of electric machines that move quickly towards your fingers. Plus, I can easily take my sewing with me anywhere. Of course, there are some gadgets I wouldn't want to live without. A year without a washing machine showed me how useful it is. But losing some gadgets has been surprisingly nice. We were watching too much TV, so I returned the rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. It's hard on the eyes but makes us focus on what's worth watching. Now, we spend more time walking the dog, reading, talking, or doing other hobbies. One of my hobbies is sewing, and I stopped using my old sewing machine. It's now a plant stand, and I can't afford a new one, so I sew by hand. We've come to believe we can't live without technology, and even if we resist the idea, we don't want to give it up. We feel sorry for past generations who had to work hard without machines. Computers now do amazing calculations and entertain us. But sewing by hand is not boring; it's relaxing. I can sew and listen to the radio or talk with family and friends. If it's a simple task, I can watch TV and feel less guilty about sitting in front of it. It's nice to sit by the fire and sew with a cup of tea. I used to think sewing by hand was hard and tiring, but it's actually soothing and satisfying to see my work improve. Things get done quickly, and life slows down to my own pace. I'm also free from the rush of modern life, where we hurry from one task to another. I've even started enjoying washing dishes by hand, dreaming while I do it. Now, I look around the house and wonder if we really need the freezer, microwave, or electric lawnmower. We could save a lot of money by not using electric lights!

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who creates beautifully crafted furniture. When I visit his workshop in East London, he seems to be in a hurry. He greets me quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" It's not clear if he's naturally brusque or just shy. His workshop is busy, filled with half-made furniture and colorful planks of wood. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and has a great reputation. He always has orders for months ahead, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen unit, Hurst is the person to go to.
Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one like Hurst, who focuses on clean, simple designs, is rare. Hurst is disappointed by some modern furniture and criticizes mass-produced, low-quality pieces. His quest for perfection and his talent are keys to his success. He is confident in his skills, saying, "I have a huge natural ability." He learned his craft by asking the right questions and learning on his own.
Most of Hurst's work comes from private clients, and some return for more pieces. He finds it satisfying to furnish a whole house. However, he admits that not all client relationships are smooth. He prefers clients who know what they want. Hurst also praises others when deserved, saying there are better craftsmen than him. He criticizes those who take too long to make one piece and those who try to make fashion statements with furniture. For Hurst, furniture should be practical and useful.
Despite his confidence, Hurst is humble about his work. As I leave, he says, "After all, I am only making furniture."

'Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This suggests that sleep is very important. However, scientists still do not fully agree on why we need to sleep so much. There are three main theories. The most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our body's health. It suggests that while we sleep, our body repairs any damage from the day and restores itself to full strength. Another theory focuses on the learning benefits of sleep. It suggests that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day, and without sleep, we would not be able to learn properly. The third theory is about energy. It says that we need sleep to recharge our energy, like recharging a battery, so we have enough energy for the next day.'

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and who does not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Most people have their own little habits or interests. It could be a love for entering newspaper contests, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to newspapers about many topics. Eccentricity is about showing our uniqueness. Inside us, there is a struggle between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains on the same track pushing against each other. One train is called individualism, and the other is conformity. For most people, conformity is stronger. We want to be accepted, loved, and feel like we belong more than we want to stand out and be different.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often gather together. They form clubs, have meetings, and organize events to share their interests or problems. They look for others who understand them, as their family and friends might see their interests as strange. Being part of a group, even a small one, is comforting.
We all feel a tension between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. Even when we follow the crowd, we don't like to admit it. We want to show our individuality, like when someone at a bar says, "I say what I think," or when a new acquaintance says, "You must take me as you find me."
At any time, we can choose to be more individualistic and show our personality. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, the American singer, said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing and pursue it without giving up, you will surprise many people." But this self-conscious individuality is not eccentricity, at least not at first. When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. However, if they continue these actions until they become a natural part of who they are, then they might be considered eccentric.
The key to eccentricity is being natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. True eccentrics are not concerned with what others think. They do what they do because of who they are. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These people are aware of the world around them and react to it. Some want to make an impression on society, and some want to escape from it, but they are all aware of it. Eccentrics, however, continue on their own path without concern for society.

**Natural Books**
We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that influenced them the most.
**A Geoffrey Lean**
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I've been lucky to meet some of the great thinkers in this field. None impressed me more than Barbara Ward, a small but powerful woman. She was deeply involved in environmental issues in post-war Europe and created her own strong ideas from her experiences. As a young journalist, she helped me understand these complex topics. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But "The Home of Man," despite its old-fashioned title even in 1976, is her most important work to me. It talks about the rapid growth of cities and the big themes she cared about, like what we now call 'sustainable development.' I've read many books since, but none have matched it.
**B Linda Bennett**
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can almost hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of their colony. This book explains the amazing world of animal communication with words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony changes from chaos to a well-organized social system. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a famous behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His work with wildlife artist Eric Ennion in this book was brilliant. Ennion's paintings, based on years of watching birds, show how one gull is aggressive and another is peaceful with just a few lines and colors. This is true art from a field naturalist.
**C Lee Durrell**
"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced me the most. It not only led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation but also confirmed my love for nature. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. I was facing many challenges, but reading this book at the end of the day made everything better. It beautifully combines animals, people, joy, and beauty, showing a world worth saving. Some say humans are the worst because of the harm we've done, but I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing the world as a family. This idea of being connected is something we all need to understand.
**D Bruce Pearson**
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after it was published in 1966. I was immediately drawn to the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds, which led me to start sketching them. But this book offered much more. Besides Ennion's beautiful paintings, it had chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even birds in music, literature, and art. This wide range of information and exciting images made me appreciate birds and nature more broadly. It showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was just as valid as a scientific one. Since I was better at art than math or physics, this book opened a new path for me.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**
We asked five top British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here’s what they said:
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in newspapers. The Book Marketing Council found that most people buy books because of reviews, more than ads, word of mouth, or bookshop displays. Authors and publishers both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are less upset by bad reviews. They think any attention, whether good or bad, can help sell books because readers want to decide for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinion of the book since they are often the first to read it.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and the press both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are still often ignored. Publishers need reviews because they help make a book and its author known. A good review by a trusted person can boost sales, especially if there are several reviews. Fame helps get books into readers' hands.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing. We rely on them because our books are not by famous authors and we don’t advertise much. Good reviews are more valuable than ads because they are seen as honest opinions. Reviews can help sell books, but they need to be combined with other things like word-of-mouth, support from bookshops, and smart marketing.
**Publisher D**  
In Britain, the link between publishing and reviews is unclear. In the U.S., a review in the New York Times can greatly affect a book’s success. In Britain, bookshops don’t always pay attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of good reviews for a writer to become popular. Some poorly reviewed books or those not reviewed at all sell very well. Non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer’s knowledge than the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want long, positive reviews. But do they sell books? I once published a biography that got great reviews, but it didn’t sell because people felt they didn’t need to buy it after reading the reviews. The reviewer’s name used to matter more, but now it’s the surprise choice of reviewer or the quality of the review that can persuade people to buy a book.

The craft of making weathervanes is very old, starting in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith keeps this tradition alive in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. "This way, I can make a special item just for them," he says. "Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want something special that shows the man's job or hobbies." 
Traditionally, weathervanes often have a cockerel design, but Graham's first weathervane was a witch on a broomstick, which he made as a surprise for his wife. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. "I realized there are endless ideas for weathervanes," he says. Graham decided to focus on making weathervanes as a business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to switch roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of their children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. "My old job wasn't creative, but this is exciting and artistic," he says. "I really enjoy designing."
Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval before cutting the design by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs in stock because they are popular too. "People like handmade things," Graham says. "They like having something a bit different." Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a small, rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love the uniqueness, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost lifelike," he says. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities by showing changes in the wind, which affect the weather," he explains. "Now, with more people moving to the countryside, they want to add a special touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like mine."
Graham is getting busier, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients around the world. Buyers from America and Denmark are especially interested. "The price," he explains, "depends on how detailed the design is." His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.

**Beginner Takes All**
Before it was even published, "The Horse Whisperer" was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it has made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about what inspired him and his success.
At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans, who was a screenwriter, producer, and wanted to be a director. His year started badly when a film project called "Life and Limb," which he had been working on for months, suddenly failed. He was very worried because he hadn't earned any money for two years, and this film was his only hope to keep his bank manager happy. A sensible person in Evans' situation might have looked for a job. He could have returned to working in television or started a TV project he had paused. Instead, he made a risky decision. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching his first novel.
Even though he was acting on a whim, the idea for the story had been with him for a while. It started when he met a farrier (a person who shoes horses) on Dartmoor while visiting a friend. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. The owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. Such people were called "horse whisperers." This story fascinated Evans. He started researching the topic to write a screenplay, as he was a filmmaker. But after "Life and Limb" failed, he decided to write it as a book.
In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he says now. "I was watching people, but I was mostly alone and felt like my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt, worried about feeding my children, and wondering if it was all a mistake."
By the end of August, he was back home and had written half of the book. "The bank manager was really pressuring us, and I needed to know if it was worth continuing. I showed it to a friend who was a literary agent; he read it and said it was 'fine.'" When asked, the agent thought Evans might get $30,000 as an advance for the book. "I knew how much I needed to pay off some of the debt and keep us going, and it was more than that. I had spent seven months on 'The Horse Whisperer,' and there were at least two more months to go. $30,000 was a tough amount. I was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book."
In October, along with the first two hundred pages of the novel, this summary was sent to seven UK publishers just before they left for the famous Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. "I said, 'You what?' And he said, 'It's OK, I just feel something is happening.'"
What happened next became famous in publishing. Within a week, after intense bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record-breaking amounts for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were shocked. We never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans says. They also didn't send it to Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for it. "My UK agent wisely involved an agent there, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief."
As they agreed to this amount, it was decided that the studios should each present their case to Evans. So, one night in October, he sat in his study while four top filmmakers called, one after the other, to ask for the chance to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel.
Evans told me all this as we drank coffee on a wooden porch above the garden of his home. He said he had since turned down an offer to write the screenplay for "The Horse Whisperer." "It's all been like a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very tough, and I don't want to become an employee of these people who I like and who have paid me so much money. I'd hate to write a draft or two and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but now we'll bring in someone else.'"
He said he would be involved, but from a distance. The success of his novel had also brought new offers to support "Life and Limb," but he wasn't sure he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

Title: Young Masters
Bobby Fischer is trying to make a comeback in the world of chess, but age is not on his side. Chess has become a game for younger players. After 20 years away from the game, Fischer is playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game with a brilliant move, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. Now, he is 49 years old, out of practice, and not in the best shape. Spassky is even older.
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, and now it is more professional. Winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure is high because players must make a certain number of moves in a set time, or they lose the game. Games are longer now, and many are played without breaks, which benefits younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. Of the top ten players in the world, eight are under 30.
The way chess is played has also changed. Much of the game happens off the board. Players must prepare well before matches, especially because computers have changed chess a lot. A small computer can store a million chess games and help players study their opponents. In one recent match, both players had teams working nonstop to find weaknesses in each other's strategies. The opening moves of a game are now studied very carefully, and being well-prepared can decide the game.
Today, there are more top-level players than ever before. Hundreds of grandmasters compete for small prize money around the world. Success requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused the whole time. Losing concentration can lead to disaster. The chess clock adds to the tension, especially during the final moments when players have only seconds to make moves. This is not a time for deep thinking; it is a battle of nerves and determination.
At the highest level, losing is very painful, while winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess competitions usually last 9-11 days, with games every day, and there are tournaments all year round. World championship matches are even tougher. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to stop because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about 10 kg during the match.
Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This made his sudden departure from chess in 1972 surprising. It made him a legend. If he returned for money, he will earn a lot. But if he came back to prove he is still the best, the result might be disappointing.

**Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some of the new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are on their way to success.
**A. Nick Grosso**
Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, has written three plays that critics love. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. "It's a low-budget film, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be more than £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." The most surprising thing about Nick is that before writing "Peaches," he had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed," he says. "It's set in a car. I wouldn't do that now because I know it's difficult to stage. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he says. "It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational environment. It was very exciting."
**B. Simon Pegg**
Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress since studying drama at Bristol University. He is writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tough tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even at Bristol, he was performing in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor and that I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has performed with the comic group Funny Business, but his work with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed me copying him," Simon admits.
**C. Ciaran McMenamin**
Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became famous when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The show was well-received, and his career took off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says with a smile. "Now I can choose what I do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was always going to succeed. Encouraged by his mother, he went from lead roles at school to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided to take it seriously because I was good at it and loved it." Now he is waiting for more praise, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about getting respect for doing good work."
**D. Neil Taylor**
Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released soon. "The record company talks about a big hit, but I have no idea. For me, if two people buy it, I'll be happy," he says. Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to get into the music business ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. There were times when I was very depressed, and I've been in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."
**E. Stephen Richards**
Poet and author Stephen Richards, 27, has won more prizes and awards than many people twice his age. He is well-known in the poetry world, where he has been touring and giving readings for the past six years. Now his first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express in a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but became unhappy with education later. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with stuffing envelopes at a theatre, I decided I should." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "My parents didn't expect me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry getting great reviews, moving to novels is brave. "There's a structure in my poetry, so there's less chance of making big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for bad writing. My main goal is not to just produce work without caring about the quality."

**Volunteer Tourism: A Discussion by Four Academic Writers**
**A.** The direct impact of volunteer tourism on development is often small. Volunteer tourists might help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot to do this work. If this money were given directly to local communities, it could hire more workers than the volunteer could replace. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often don't have the necessary skills or experience. Many studies question whether gap year volunteering is truly about helping others or if it's more about gaining experiences that help in future careers. However, these projects might help volunteers become more ethical and caring in their future lives and careers.
**B.** Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution, and more participation in global issues through civic organizations. It can also create international social networks among regular people. In this way, the benefits for both volunteers and host communities can contribute to the global good. However, if volunteering is mostly done by people from wealthier countries, it might only give these volunteers a broader perspective and career advantages, without helping those who don't have access to such opportunities. Volunteers might use these experiences to advance personally, using host communities as a step up.
**C.** At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that benefits the volunteer more than the community, or as a way for wealthy Westerners to advance their careers. At its best, it can benefit both volunteers and the organizations they work with, allowing for an exchange of skills and cultural experiences. Importantly, volunteering can increase awareness and commitment to fighting inequality, poverty, and unsustainable development.
**D.** Volunteer tourism fits with the trend of wanting to help others. These efforts, aimed at making a small difference, can seem positive in a world that is often skeptical of politics. The personal approach is appealing because it avoids big government and business. However, it also skips the democratic process and reduces development to individual acts of charity, often not addressing the root causes of poverty. Criticism of volunteering is not entirely fair, as it can be simple, good-hearted charity. But when volunteer tourism is promoted as sustainable development, it can weaken the true meaning of development. The politics of volunteer tourism can ignore the social reasons behind global inequalities and poverty in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**
Many of us listen to the radio in the morning and need something to help us get out of bed. That's why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models.
One model has a 'dual alarm function,' but it doesn't work as expected. You can't snooze with the buzzer and then wake up later. The instructions suggest setting two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends, but not everyone needs that. This model is priced similarly to another one we tested, but it includes a cassette player, which is a good deal. You can fall asleep to your own tapes and wake up without news. We liked the radio quality, but it's as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails. This model was the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges loved it, although the clock on his test model got stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with grey numbers on a green background. The snooze bar is wide, so you can tap it with your eyes closed. However, the buttons are so smooth that I kept touching them like piano keys, which was confusing. The clock has a backup power feature, so you don't have to reset it if the plug is pulled out. We all liked this feature, but setting it up was difficult, though we felt 'cool' and sophisticated once we figured it out.
Tom Granger thought the model with a built-in lamp was 'tacky.' You have to pull the light out of its socket to use it, which made him question its quality. He had to read the instructions twice to make it work, and the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The light is hard to position and only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges liked the lamp idea but agreed the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer is loud and annoying, like a submarine alarm. Surprisingly, this model is the third most popular on the market.
Aimed at young people, another model has a bright casing and a bootlace strap. Tom Granger and I liked it because it stands out. It was the only one we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm can be off by 20 minutes, either early or late. Paul Bridges thought this was ridiculous and said the model was 'fiddly' and 'useless.'
The simplest and cheapest model was liked by Tom Granger because it was 'standard' and took up little space. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which he found intuitive. With modern push-button tuning, you're never sure if you've pressed the buttons correctly. He admitted that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was basic, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed the radio quality was fine. The buzzer worked well, getting me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs
A hedgehog is a small animal known for the sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not originally from America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they feel threatened, which makes their spines stick out to protect them. How well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines because they have evolved to be lighter. These hedgehogs might try to run away from danger first and only roll into a ball if they have no other choice. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, usually under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. If the weather is good, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**
Excelling in sports is challenging for everyone, but women often face extra difficulties. They have to train hard and make sacrifices, leaving little time for a normal life. Despite these challenges, many women are overcoming obstacles and setting new records. Here, we talk to some talented British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.
**A. Jill, 27, Skier**
"It's amazing to fly through the air and land perfectly, but it can be scary. Sometimes you feel unwell or it's windy, but you just keep going. It's hard to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months a year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women in the British team. We all compete on the same courses and are treated equally—it's a young sport."
**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race and won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was surprising since I'd never cycled before! I'm well-paid as a professional, and cycling has many opportunities for sponsorships. However, I worry people might think I succeed because of my looks, not my skills. So, I focus on cycling rather than making money. I train at least four hours every day on the bike, plus stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is a cyclist too, so he understands the time commitment."
**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**
"Rowing is hard for girls to start because few girls' schools offer it. Most start at 19 or 20, making it harder to succeed internationally. Also, coaches often stay for only a year, so there's no consistency, and the women's team is disorganized. But it's fun, I love being fit, and there's a good social life."
**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**
"At 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how big it was! Britain felt too small and safe. I was stubborn and hated being controlled. Now I'm more tactful. Each walk is different. Walking across Australia was the most painful experience. I walked 50 miles and 21 hours each day with only three hours of sleep, in high temperatures, and with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record! I had to, because my sponsorship money was running out after 95 days. Men often think women are more likely to fail, so sponsoring them is seen as risky."
**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**
"Some men have big egos when driving—you see it on highways. When I do well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has its downsides. At corners, men think 'I've got to beat her,' so I've had many collisions! You need to be naturally competitive and aggressive. It's hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and were seen as unusual. It's great that more women are racing every year. For me, the appeal of saloon car racing is aiming for perfection, always trying to complete a perfect lap."
**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**
"I get up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evening, I cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There's a lot of nervous anticipation before a race, and you push yourself hard—you don't feel good if you don't. I've often asked myself why I do it. The answers are: a) I'm happier when I'm fit, b) I'm lazy at heart and would be worse if I didn't do this, c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the press, 90% of the article is about the men's event, and only 10% mentions the women's event. The prize money isn't as good either. But we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission, so we're working on it."

Title: The Day I Met Picasso
Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso, one of the most famous artists of the century. At 18 years old, Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco before starting university. He was low on money and found a job painting boats in Cannes. One day, while eating at a restaurant in Cannes harbor, he saw Picasso, who was known to be a private person. Picasso was sitting with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends.
Encouraged by a friend, Richard nervously approached Picasso to ask for his autograph. To his surprise, Picasso agreed and signed Richard's sketchbook. He even added a playful drawing on the page. Richard was thrilled and started a conversation with Picasso, using an American woman at the table as an interpreter because Picasso's English was not good.
After showing his friend the autograph, Richard was encouraged to go back and draw Picasso's portrait. Without asking for permission, Richard started drawing Picasso, who made funny faces to make it difficult for him. Despite the challenge, Richard continued drawing, feeling that Picasso was testing his determination. Eventually, Picasso stopped moving and allowed Richard to study him closely. Richard noticed how youthful and intense Picasso's eyes were, despite his age.
When Richard finished, Picasso wanted to see the portrait. Although Richard was embarrassed, Picasso looked at it and nodded. Then, Picasso took Richard's crayon and quickly drew a playful face on the paper. Richard was amazed by Picasso's skill and creativity. He asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso declined, saying Richard already had his signature.
Looking back, Richard feels very lucky to have met Picasso and received his attention. It was a memorable experience for him.

**Talking Shop: How Stores Make You Spend More**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here are some tricks that shops use to make you spend more money.
**A. The Image of Freshness**
Supermarkets know that customers love fresh products. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance to make the store look fresh. They might also have a bakery inside, so the smell of fresh bread fills the air. The store might use green colors because people associate green with freshness. Most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, doesn't match this fresh image.
**B. Displaying to Advantage**
Where products are placed in a store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas of the store are most popular. They put high-profit items or fast-selling products in these spots. Products at eye level sell better, so manufacturers want their items there. Special offer bins attract people who love bargains. Stores also use 'complementation' by placing related items together, like salad dressings near salads.
**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**
Supermarkets put basic items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by other tempting products. Chain stores do the same with popular items, placing them far from the entrance. They hope loyal customers will look for these items and see other products along the way.
**D. Less Sells More**
Chain stores have changed how they display products. The Next chain, for example, uses a 'boutique' style, showing fewer items to make them seem exclusive. Even though their clothes are mass-produced, the store design makes them look special.
**E. Tempting Totals**
Food shoppers care more about the total bill than individual prices. Supermarkets mix low-profit staples with high-profit items. They might sell some items at a loss to attract customers, known as 'loss leaders.' They also buy in large quantities to get discounts from manufacturers.
**F. The All-Important Price Tag**
In chain stores, shoppers buy fewer items and notice prices more. Pricing something at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This also helps reduce theft, as staff must record the sale to give change.
**G. Lighting to Effect**
Both supermarkets and chain stores use lighting carefully. Chain stores aim for natural light so clothes look the same as they would outside. Supermarkets use special lighting to make fresh food look better.
**H. Walk This Way**
Chain stores use different flooring to guide shoppers. One type of carpet marks the path, and another marks sales areas. This encourages shoppers to follow the path and explore sales areas. Marks and Spencer, for example, use wood or marble for paths and carpet for sales areas.
**I. In-Store Promotion**
When you enter a supermarket, you might see big photos of delicious food. In the U.S., some supermarkets use 'video trolleys' with screens that show ads as you shop. These trolleys target impulse buyers and can increase sales by about 30%.

Chris Bonnington, a 58-year-old mountaineer, is famous for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written books like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way." Robin Knox-Johnston, aged 53, started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-69, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic, taking 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard. Chris and Robin teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in a book called "Sea, Ice and Rock."
In 1979, while working on "Quest for Adventure," Chris contacted Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail, where Chris could teach him some climbing skills, and Robin could teach Chris the basics of sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed for a while, then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin went to the shore to practice climbing. The climb was challenging, but Robin was calm and steady. When they reached a big drop, Chris showed Robin how to climb down safely. Robin, used to climbing down ropes on his boat, managed to lower himself safely.
During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a bigger version of their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin as a leader. Although the skipper usually makes all the decisions, Robin asked for everyone's opinion first. Even though most people were too shy to give advice, it was nice to be included in the decision-making.
Chris found the sailing part of the trip boring and difficult. He preferred being on land and wasn't very handy with fixing things. Robin, on the other hand, was a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or the toilet. Chris sometimes felt useless and found it hard to be so close to the crew on a small yacht. When they reached Greenland, Chris led the climbing part of the expedition. He was worried about Robin's safety because if Robin fell, he could pull Chris down with him. Climbing Greenland's highest mountain, the Cathedral, was harder than Chris expected. Robin wasn't a natural climber, but he did very well. On their first attempt, they climbed for 24 hours straight and were so tired they almost fell asleep on steep slopes. Robin trusted Chris completely and followed his lead. Even though Robin was worried about the boat, he was eager to try climbing the mountain again.
The only time Chris and Robin had a disagreement was on the yacht on the way home. They took turns keeping watch, and Chris was supposed to get up at 4 am. Robin decided not to wake him because he thought he could handle it himself. Chris felt Robin didn't trust him, but Robin quickly reassured him that wasn't the case. By the end of the Greenland expedition, Chris realized that Robin, despite his tough exterior, was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**
**Early Apples 8,000 BC**  
People have been eating apples since prehistoric times. In ancient Britain, they spat out apple seeds, and 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people even stored dried apple halves for winter. These were wild crab apples, small and wrinkled, known in ancient Britain as 'windings'. They were very different from the apples we know today.
**Norman Influence 1000 AD**  
The French learned fruit-growing skills from the Romans, which they developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. The Romans introduced the dessert apple, Decio, but most Roman apples didn't suit the British climate. Norman apple varieties became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and develop new apples, and many Western apples today come from these varieties.
**Medieval Favorites 1200**  
In the 13th century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, recorded in 1204, was the main dessert apple until the 18th century. Its cooking partner was the Costard, sold in Oxford markets from 1296 to the 17th century, giving us the word 'costermonger' for someone who sells fruit and vegetables on the street. However, apple production declined due to droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses. More apples were imported until the 16th century when Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and created the first modern orchard in Kent.
**Settler Treasure 1750**  
By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers to America. In North America, John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed', planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. He was seen as a medicine man by the Indians and became a folk hero.
**Modern Delicious 1850**  
Around this time in Iowa, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree growing from a dead tree's roots. He named the apple 'Hawkey'. At a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, 'Delicious, delicious!'. In 1895, it was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples in the world.
**Granny Smith 1850**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She was the daughter of convicts and worked as a midwife in New South Wales. Known as 'Granny Smith', she managed her family's farm and orchard. In 1868, she found a small tree growing from discarded fruit. She transplanted it and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. She said, 'It's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish', referring to both the fruit and her convict origins.
**Uniformity 1950**  
Today, apples are grown worldwide, from India to Africa. Most are grown commercially and come from just a few varieties, chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well, not for taste. This uniformity is reducing the variety of apples. While UK gardeners have preserved many old varieties, the US has lost most of its apples from 100 years ago. Consumers are now asking for more variety. We must protect natural diversity in apples and other foods for everyone's benefit.
